waiting.title: Welcome to $t(appNameWithDefiniteArticle)!
text: Thanks for using our app. Find all our code on:

waiting.title: How can I get a device?
text: You can buy a BitBox in our online shop:

waiting.title: I lost my device. Now what?
text: You can recover your accounts on a new BitBox or with our backup center.

waiting.title: Does this app require an Internet connection?
text: Yes, an Internet connection is required to synchronize the wallet, send transactions and retrieve latest exchange rates.

waitingWithoutDevice.title: Can I use the app without a device?
text: Unfortunately, this is not yet possible at the moment.
Luckily, you are currently in developer mode and can simply enter a PIN, from which a seed is derived deterministically (i.e. without additional randomness).

accountDescription.title: What is displayed here?
accountDescription.text: This is your account overview. It shows incoming and outgoing transactions. The balance is displayed for each account separately. Consult the guide in settings to learn more about the different account types.

accountSendDisabled.title: Why can't I send any {{unit}}?
accountSendDisabled.text: Your balance may not be zero, otherwise you cannot cover the network fee.

accountTransactionLabel.title: Which address is displayed for each transaction?
accountTransactionLabel.text: It is the address where you received the coins or sent the coins to. An address encodes how (and thus by whom) the coins can be spent.

accountTransactionTime.title: What time is displayed?
accountTransactionTime.text: The time the transaction has been confirmed on the blockchain.

accountTransactionAttributes.title: What is the info shown in the transaction details?
text: Confirmations: Number of blocks that have been added to the block that contains the transaction. We recommend to wait for at least three confirmations before you consider a payment as settled.
Transaction ID: Used to look up a transaction in an external block explorer.
Virtual size: Used to determine network fee. You have successfully saved on fees if it is smaller than the size of the transaction.
Size: Actual transaction size in bytes when serialized according to the Bitcoin protocol.

Weight: Introduced with Segwit, it is a new metric to evaluate transaction and block sizes. Each segregated witness byte counts as one, everything else as four weight units. Instead of one megabyte in actual size, the block size limit is now four million weight units.
Fee: Amount the miner received that included the transaction in a block. To learn more, click on the send button.

accountIncomingBalance.title: What does incoming mean?
accountIncomingBalance.text: Incoming sums up the amounts that are being transferred to you but have not yet been confirmed by the network.

accountTransactionConfirmation.title: What is a pending transaction?
accountTransactionConfirmation.text: This is a transaction that has been broadcasted to the network and is waiting to be confirmed.

accountFiat.title: Can I display other conversion rates?
accountFiat.text: Yes, you can click on any ticker to rotate through several fiat currencies. Moreover, you can change the list of currencies in the settings.

accountRates.title: Which rates are used?
accountRates.text: The exchange rates are updated every minute from CryptoCompare.

receive.title: What do I do with an address?
text: Give it to others to send you some coins.
(Try to independently verify the address, for example with a phone call.)

receive.title: Why are there many addresses?
text: For privacy and security reasons, you should never hand out the same address twice. Click on 'Next' to get a new address for a different purpose. You can generate up to 20 addresses at a time. All addresses are derived from your single backup seed. (Think of addresses like invoice numbers.)

receive.title: Why should I verify the address securely?
text: One of the reasons for buying a hardware wallet like the BitBox is that you should not trust your computer due to its big attack surface. Consequently, you should not trust your computer to generate and display authentic addresses. The button to verify the address securely makes the BitBox send the address to a paired mobile phone, from which you can also scan and verify the QR code.

receive.title: How can I verify an address securely?
text: Click on the BitBox icon in the sidebar on the left and see the Pairing section. Continue reading the guide over there.

receive.title: When do the addresses change?
text: As soon as one of the addresses is used in a transaction, new addresses are added to the list such that 20 unused addresses are available again.

send.title: Why is there a network fee?
text: Bitcoin transactions are competing to be confirmed by a miner. Miners choose transactions to be included in the blockchain based on their fee.

Miners vote on the history of transactions. Since there is no trusted third party to enforce one vote per person (which is the whole point of blockchains), miners vote on transactions by sacrificing a costly resource like computing power. As a reward for their work, they can claim newly created coins and the fee of all the transactions they included.

send.title: What is the network priority?
text: The higher fee you are willing to pay, the faster your transaction is typically confirmed by the network.

send.title: How is the fee determined?
text: The fee is based on the transaction data size and not its amount. The fee targets are calculated by a bitcoin client for each network priority you chose. They are shown if they have a different value from the target below.
Economy: 24 blocks (around 4 hours for Bitcoin, 1 hour for Litecoin)
Low: 12 blocks (around 2 hours for Bitcoin, 30 minutes for Litecoin)
Normal: 6 blocks (around 1 hour for Bitcoin, 15 minutes for Litecoin)
High: 2 blocks (around 20 minutes for Bitcoin, 5 minutes for Litecoin)
(A block takes on average ten minutes for Bitcoin (2.5 minutes in Litecoin) to mine and the network load may vary considerably in the above periods.)

send.title: Can I revert a transaction?
text: Once a transaction is signed and sent (i.e. broadcasted to the network), it can no longer be reverted. Verify the transactions (including the fee) properly before signing!
If you know the recipient and he or she is willing to send the same amount (minus the transaction fees) back to you, you can send them a new receiving address.

settings.title: Why are there multiple accounts for the same coin?
text: Some cryptocurrencies have multiple address and transaction formats. These addresses are separated into extra accounts.

settings.title: What is Bitcoin Legacy?
text: This uses an old transaction format, which has been superseded by the Segwit address and transaction formats. If you used the BitBox with the old desktop app before, this is the account containing your coins currently. To save fees in the future transfer them to the Bitcoin account with a transaction to an address in the Bitcoin or Bitcoin bech32 account.

settings.title: What is the Bitcoin account?
text: This is a backwards-compatible segwit account (p2sh-p2wpkh). It uses a new transaction format that saves you network fees. The address format is similar to legacy, and as such can be used with all existing Bitcoin wallets/exchanges/services.

settings.title: What is Bitcoin bech32?
text: To reap the full benefits of segwit's cheaper network fees, Bitcoin bech32 should be used. It uses a new address format called bech32, but this format is not accepted everywhere yet.

bitbox.title: How can I eject the BitBox?
text: You can unplug the BitBox at any time without having to eject it first.

bitbox.title: How can I eject the SD card?
text: You can remove the SD card from the BitBox at any time as long as you are not in the process of creating or restoring a backup.

bitbox.title: How to securely pair with your phone
text: After having downloaded our mobile app for either iOS or Android, you scan the displayed QR code, which sets up a secure channel between the mobile app and this application. Afterwards, a secret key shared between the mobile phone and the BitBox is generated. Just follow the instructions in the mobile app.

bitbox.title: What is a hidden wallet?
text: It is a second wallet on the same device protected by a different PIN and recovery key, which you can use for plausible deniability.

bitbox.title: Which servers does this app talk to?
text: This app communicates with servers of Shift Cryptosecurity to check for updates, load transactions, and send information to paired mobile apps.
Additionally, it retrieves the latest exchange rates from CryptoCompare. (The conversions are calculated locally, no amounts of yours are transmitted.)

backups.title: What is a backup?
text: It is a copy of the seed on an SD card. The seed together with your recovery key generates your wallet.

backups.title: Can I encrypt the backup?
text: No but your recovery key is required to derive the wallet from the stored seed.

backups.title: How often do I have to make a backup?
text: The backup is automatically generated when a new wallet is created. You only have to make a new backup if your SD card is lost or damaged, or if you want to use multiple SD cards as backups. You do not need to create new backups after any transaction activity. All your transaction data can be recreated by your single backup that was automatically generated for you.

unlock.title: I already have a device with a password, how do I unlock?
text: If you set up your BitBox previously with a password, you can use it to unlock the device. Just enter it in the PIN input field.

unlock.title: What do I do if I forgot the PIN?
text: You have to reset the device and restore the wallet from a backup.

unlock.title: How do I reset the device?
text: Enter a wrong PIN 15 times. The last few attempts require a long touch on the device.

initialize.title: What is the PIN used for?
text: The PIN is used to authenticate access to the device and to encrypt the communication.

initialize.title: What happens if I forget the PIN?
text: If you forget the PIN, you have to reset the device and restore the wallet from a backup.

seed.title: Recovery key tips
text: The recovery key is your last line of defence. Creating a strong recovery key that is easy to remember and difficult for a computer to guess is hard. We recommend using a short list of words, that you can remember with a simple story, like correcthorsebatterystaple (use your favorite search engine to lookup the comic behind it). We also recommend that you write it down and store it an a safe place.

seed.title: Tips for SD card storage
text: Store it somewhere safe. One of the reasons for using the BitBox is that your computer is too vulnerable to handle private keys for cryptocurrencies. Remove it from the BitBox and do not insert it into your computer.

seed.title: Can I print the backup on the SD card?
text: You can print it, since the seed is stored in a PDF on the SD card. However, you should either insert the SD card directly into a non-networked printer or use a different computer, which ideally is never online. Alternatively, you can back up the seed on several SD cards instead.

seed.title: Why can't I change the recovery key later on?
text: If you enter a different recovery key, a different wallet is derived. The same recovery key will produce the same wallet.
